newsitem.title: GERMANY: BUBA'S SIEVERT SAYS INSTITUTE FORECASTS REALISTIC.
newsitem.headline: BUBA'S SIEVERT SAYS INSTITUTE FORECASTS REALISTIC.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Olaf Sievert said on Tuesday that growth forecasts made earlier in the day by Germany's six leading economic research institutes were realistic.
In a semi-annual report, the six institutes said German gross domestic product was likely to grow 1.5 percent in 1996, rising to 2.5 percent growth in 1997.
"The research institutes expect gross domestic product growth of 1.5 percent for all of Germany this year," Sievert said. "That is realistic to me, as is the forecast for next year."
Sievert, who is head of the Bundesbank's branch in Saxony and Thueringen, said the mood in German industry had improved since the summer, brightened above all by improved demand from abroad.
He also noted that efforts German industry has made to make itself more competitive were starting to pay off.
